canvases.label: Principia Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica, Title page

metadata.value: Title page of Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica, Latin for "Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy", often referred to as simply the Principia, a work in three books by Sir Isaac Newton, first published in London in July 1687. Newton (25 December 1642 20 March 1727) was an English physicist and mathematician, and is widely regarded as one of the most influential scientists of all time and a key figure in the scientific revolution. His Principia laid the foundations for most of classical mechanics and formulated the laws of motion and universal gravitation that were to dominate scientists' view of the physical universe for the next three centuries.
metadata.label: Description
